case_vignette: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of back pain for the past six months. The pain is worse with exercise and when reclining. He attends high school and is on the swim team. He also states that he lifts weights on a regular basis. He has not had any trauma to the back or any previous problems with his joints. He has no history of serious illness. His father has a disc herniation. Palpation of the spinous processes at the lumbosacral area shows that two adjacent vertebrae are displaced and are at different levels. Muscle strength is normal. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is intact throughout. When the patient is asked to walk, a waddling gait is noted. Passive raising of either the right or left leg causes pain radiating down the ipsilateral leg.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing back pain for the past six months that gets worse with exercise and when I lie back.
Do you experience any other symptoms such as morning stiffness or pain in other joints?
No, I haven't had any morning stiffness or pain in other joints.
Have you had any recent injuries or changes in your physical activity level?
No, I haven't had any recent injuries or changes in my physical activity level.
Does the pain improve with rest or does it remain constant regardless of your activity level?
The pain is worse with exercise and when reclining, so it doesn't improve with rest.
Have you noticed any changes in your bowel or bladder habits since the onset of your back pain?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in my bowel or bladder habits.
Do you have any family history of chronic back issues or autoimmune diseases?
My father has a disc herniation, but there's no history of autoimmune diseases in my family.
Have you tried any medications or therapies for your back pain, and if so, did anything provide relief?
No, I haven't tried any medications or therapies for my back pain yet.
Final Diagnosis: Disc Herniation
